moves.1. e4 Nf6: I don't often meet Alekhine's Defence.  The idea of the opening is for Black to encourage White to overreach himself and then to strike back, exploiting the holes in White's defences.  So in planning to meet it, White either has to guard against over-exuberance or make sure that his attack wins quickly - not an option against a decent player of the Black pieces.
moves.2. e5 Nd5 3. d4 d6 4. exd6 Qxd6: ? Exposing Black's Queen too early in the game.  This contradicts opening principles generally and in the Alekhine particularly.  4...exd6 or 4....cxd6 were much safer.
moves.5. Bc4 Qb4+: ? a second Queen move before Black has developed his other pieces.  However, White must be careful not to try to "punish" his opponent too soon or he will also fail to develop quickly.
moves.6. Nd2: blocking the check, developing the N and defending the B all with one move
moves.6... c6: probably the wrong pawn as this deprives the Nb8 of its natural square and fails to allow the Bf8 room to breathe.  On the other hand, if Black is making so many mistakes in the opening, why did it take 68 moves for me to finish him off?!
moves.7. c3 Qa5 8. Ngf3 g6: so now the Bf8 is going to g7 where it will bite on granite.  Another strange choice by my higher-rated opponent.
moves.9. O-O Bg7 10. Re1 O-O 11. Bxd5: ?  An unusual choice by me.  I usually prefer to keep my Bs and swap off Ns.  It removes the defender of e7, but I don't think it is justified for tactical or strategic reasons - only material.
moves.11... cxd5 12. Rxe7 Nc6 13. Re1: The pawn has cost me the two bishops, allowed Black to develop his N on an ideal square and cost me two tempi.  I don't think I should have grabbed this pawn at all!  On the other hand, black is saddled with an immobile isolated pawn, so it's not all bad.
moves.13... Bf5 14. Nb3 Qc7 15. Bg5: developing my last minor piece to a good square, controlling d8, the natural square from which to defend d5.
moves.15... Rfe8 16. Qd2 b6: to prevent my N coming to c5, I think.
moves.17. Nh4 Bd7 18. Bf4 Qb7 19. Nf3: its work is done on h4.  Time to recentralise as soon as possible.  It also removes the risk of a fork from g5 if my Q is distracted by other duties.
moves.19... Rxe1+: An interesting decision.  As the defender, Black decides to eliminate the rooks.  I'm happy to swap one pair but would like to keep the other on the board as long as I don't cede the e-file.
mission accomplished but now Black has to guard against back-rank threats from my dominant Q
moves.26. Qxe2 h6 27. Bd6 Qc8: Counter-attacking White's c-pawn while defending the back rank.
moves.39. Ng4: but I'm determined to exploit my material advantage...
Now Black has a prime asset in his remote passed pawn but while so many pieces are still on the board, it is not yet a winning advantage.  White still has one more pawn and his pieces are well placed.
moves.55... Nc4 56. Nxc4 dxc4 57. Ke3: Bishops of opposite colours give Black good drawing chances, especially with the remote passed pawn but white's two sets of connected pawns give him hope for splitting Black's King's attention and forcing one pawn home.
?! The bishop prevents White from playing 60. Kf5  but I think an advance on the black squares would have been OK, supporting the g-pawn.
moves.60... Ke6 61. Kf4 Kf6 62. d5: As planned, Black's K can't stop both pawns, can he?
moves.62... Bg6 63. g5+ Kf7 64. Ke5 Ke8 65. Kf: ! Avoiding the error of placing the pawn on g7, when White's K would not be able to get next to g8 to defend it when it queens.  Black resigned.

gameName: Didcot 1 vs Oxford City 2, Oxford & District League Div 1
